div1.p: In response to the varying questions asked by Mr. Minister of the United States of America, he provided him the following statements:

I.- The Commerce is absolutely free in the Independant State of the Congo. All specifics can sell to the residents all goods and buy the products of their work. However, the trafficking of advanced firearms is prohibited. The spirited wind of the natives is equally prohibited in the almost the entire State, with the exception of one part of the Bas Congo.

It goes without saying that with a property in an ordinary exploitation, il faut au Congo comme partout ailleurs, the authorization of the property. Also the products, notably they ivory and the rubber, come from the State forests and cannot be harvested withouth authorization from the owner. The authorization granted, with what concerns the unsold or conceded forests, to the subects of all the nationalities, in the river bassins Kassï, Sankuru, Lubefu, Loango, Djuma, Ubangi, on the Congo rivers downstream of the FAlls, in the Lulonga bassin, in the Ikelemba and the Ruki. (Decreed the 30th of October 1892 on the exploitation of rubber and the later placement).

II.- There are no formalities to fulfill for excercising any commerce. If one acts to establish any societal trade, the status of this society must be deposed to the courts administration service of the Tribunal to the primary authority, in Boma.
The religious associations don't legally recognize that by the grant of the civil personification; this one demands by the adressed requê to the Governor General,
she grants by the order of the Sovereign King.
The imports and exports of merchandise are subject to the formalities of customs officers indicated in the regulations enclosed (Annexs I and II).

III.- Every person who wants to buy or take other land for lease on which it exists, for the profit of the outsiders, the owner's rights duly noted, must do it the demande either to the Secretary of State in Brussels, or the Governer General in Boma.
IV.- The principle taxes to acquit in the Congo are 1o le rix d'achat or from renting the proptery, if they belong to the domaine of the State. (Annex III_)
4o The exit and entrance fees (See annexs I and II attached);
5o The state tax ont he rubber. This tax is 0.25 frs. per kilogram of harvested rubber. The rubber provennant the territories downriver of Stanley-Pool, the Ubangi rivers is not subject to this tax;
6o Tax on the recruitment of the workers (See annex VI, attached, page 151).
All of these taxes can be modified by law, with exception to the rights of entrance that has been established in accordance with the powers.
V.-The Conglese laws, in accordance with the Act of Berlin, contain no distinction relative to the nationality from particulars or from societies.
